channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #55 - YAPC::EU in less than a week in Frankfurt
item.description:
Hi,

in case you have not heard about it yet, the next major Perl event is going to be next week in Frankfurt, Germany. For details check the bottom of this newsletter where I usually list the 3-4 nearest Perl event.

This week we saw the release of perl 5.16.1 and the packaging of Strawberry Perl. There was also a very mail in the Perl 5 Porters mailing list coming from an enthusiastic Perl developer. It's nice to see some people thanking the perl core developers for their hard work.

Next week I am going to send the weekly from Frankfurt. Till then, enjoy the articles:

item.title: Marpa v. Perl regexes: a rematch
item.description: How fast can you find balanced sets of parentheses in a string of parentheses? That's the benchmark Jeffrey Kegler ran again with the latest version of Marpa. Plenty of links also included to the earlier results and to an explanation: What is Marpa?

item.title: Should my Perl release process be yours?
item.description: brian d foy goes philosophical on why you should use the exact same process as he does. Or why should you not do that. In any case, it is up to you to decide.

item.title: Blio - my blogging 'engine'
item.description: Thomas Klausner (domm) has released his blogging 'engine' which is similar to so many other - static page engines. You are not expected to try it.

item.title: CPAN modules for checking credit card numbers (LUHN check)
item.description: A new awesome comparison by Neil Bowers. This time he took a look at 9 modules, including one from the Acme namespace which quite surprised me.

item.title: Some Meta Fun With Moose and Avro
CGI.pm vs Templates
item.description: Do you use the HTML generating capabilities of CGI.pm? After reading the article by Dave Cross you might reconsider.

item.title: What is your release process?
item.description: This is the article, and the discussion that followed it, that triggered the article by brian d foy. Steven Haryanto explained his process and a few people chipped in with theirs.

item.title: Test and Debug Your Web Applications with Tamper Data
CPAN Testers Summary - July 2012 - Head On The Door
From ODT to POD with Perl
item.description: An explanation how to take an Open Office document, and extract the text from it using XML manipulation.

item.title: How to create Origami envelopes using Perl
item.description: I love it when people do nice things with Perl. I don't mean nice code, but nice results. Like in this case Flavio Poletti took a nice images, manipulated it a bit and created a printable PDF. All that using Image::Magick.

item.title: Spanish Localization of the Perl Core Documentation - Grant Report #2
item.description: Current status around 45% completed.

item.title: Devel::Cover Grant Report for July
item.description: One question stands out: Are you using Devel::Cover on anything else than *nix or Windows? If yes, please contact Paul Johnson ASAP! He needs your input. - Actually even if you are using it on Windows or *nix you can contact him and thank him for his work!

item.title: To gdb or not to gdb
item.description: Another post from the series of Rocky Bernstein while he is writing the new debugger. In this article he is discussing the question how much he should follow the established standard of gdb, and how much can he go on new, maybe better directions? He also helps us a bit to look around and see what happens in two different implementations of Ruby: MRI and Rubinius.

item.title: DC.PM Podcast Moved
item.description: Zachary Zebrowski let us know about the new location of the podcasts from the Washington D.C. Perl Mongers. He also mentioned, that the software used to create the podcasts is not available on Github. I don't know the podcast recording market, but it would be awesome if this was turned into a product that random people - and not just Perl programmers and Linux sysadmins - could use.

item.title: Damian Conway weighs in on new features, best practices and Perl's future
item.description: A 10 minute interview with Damian Conway.

item.title: Perl 6 subroutines
item.description: This Perl Maven article gives you a little taste in the world of subroutines and signatures in Perl 6 along with slurpy arrays. You even get a glimpse at the reduction operator.

item.title: Perl 5 to Perl 6 - Scalars
item.description: In this article I tried to tackle some of the most common string functions of Perl 5 and explain how they changed, or not, in Perl 6.

item.title: Perl School
item.description: Dave Cross ran a free Perl course in London. This is his conclusion how it went and how he is going to improve, both the content and the commitment from the students. IMHO charging money can create some commitment and makes people value the course more. Even if it is a small amount.

item.title: Lausanne classes
item.description: Damian Conway returns to Lausanne and London, and who knows where else.

item.title: Perl 5 Porters Weekly: July 30-August 5, 2012
item.description: I especially liked the 'Perl Saves SysAd Bacon' part.

item.title: Enlightened Modern Perl or useful Perl?
item.description: OK, this is not the only link from my sites, but this is not with technical content. It is a dilemma I have. You might want to share your opinion.

item.title: YAPC::EU 2012
item.description: August 20-22, 2012, Frankfurt, Germany

item.title: Moving to Moose Hackathon
item.description: August 25-30, Preikestolen Mountain Lodge, near Stavanger, Norway

item.title: YAPC::Asia Tokyo 2012
item.description: September 27-29, 2012, Tokyo, Japan

item.title: Portuguese Perl workshop (PTPW)
item.description: September 28, 2012, Braga, Portugal
